citation.article-title: Desulfovibrio alaskensis sp. nov., a sulphate-reducing bacterium from a soured oil reservoir.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Desulfovibrio alaskensis sp. nov.
Desulfovibrio alaskensis (al.ask.en′sis. N.L. masc. adj. alaskensis from Alaska, referring to the place of isolation).
Cells occur singly and are motile by means of a single polar flagellum.
Grows at pH 6·5–8·5, 10–45 °C and in 0–10 % (w/v) NaCl.
Maximum growth rate under optimal growth conditions in marine Postgate medium C [37 °C, pH 7·0 and 2·5 % (w/v) NaCl] using lactate as carbon source is 0·133 h−1.
Vitamins are not required for growth.
Strictly anaerobic, reduces sulphate, sulphite and thiosulphate, producing sulphide.
Nitrate is not used as an electron acceptor.
Substrates that are oxidized by sulphate reduction are lactate, pyruvate and succinate.
Ethanol and butanol can be utilized fermentatively (for a limited number of generations).
Major cellular fatty acids are C18 : 0, isoC15 : 0 and isoC17 : 1ω7c.
The type strain is Al1T (=NCIMB 13491T=DSM 16109T), isolated from the production fluids of offshore oilfields in Alaska.
